name: Ottawa
fun_fact: Fun fact: Ottawa's Rideau Canal transforms into the world's largest naturally frozen skating rink every winter! The 7.8-kilometer UNESCO World Heritage skateway has the equivalent surface area of 90 Olympic hockey rinks. Since 1971, nearly one million visitors glide down the canal each winter (averaging 20,000 daily), skating past Parliament Hill while munching on hot BeaverTails and sipping hot chocolate.

hero_dishes.name: BeaverTails
hero_dishes.description: Iconic Canadian fried dough pastry stretched into a beaver tail shape, topped with cinnamon sugar, chocolate hazelnut spread, maple, or s'mores
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in 1978 in Ottawa's ByWard Market when the Hooker family turned their Killaloe, Ontario recipe for fried dough into a business. The first stand opened in ByWard Market, and now BeaverTails stands pop up along the frozen Rideau Canal in winter. President Obama famously ate one in 2009, creating the 'Obama Cookie' at Moulin de Provence bakery.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Original ByWard Market location, stands along Rideau Canal Skateway in winter. A true Ottawa tradition - gliding down the canal on skates then warming up with a piping hot BeaverTail while viewing Parliament Hill.

hero_dishes.name: Poutine
hero_dishes.description: The iconic Canadian comfort food: mountain of golden fries topped with squeaky cheese curds and rich brown gravy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in rural Quebec in the 1950s, poutine crossed the Ottawa River to become an Ottawa staple. The name means 'a mess' in Quebec slang. Ottawa offers creative variations reflecting the city's diversity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Throughout Ottawa in endless variations: butter chicken poutine (Indian-inspired), duck confit poutine (gourmet), peameal bacon poutine (Ontario twist). ByWard Market has numerous poutineries.

hero_dishes.name: Shawarma
hero_dishes.description: Middle Eastern spit-roasted meat wrapped in pita with tahini, garlic sauce, pickles, and vegetables
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ottawa is called the 'Shawarma Capital of Canada' with over 200 restaurants serving this Middle Eastern delicacy. The city's vibrant multiculturalism and large Lebanese community made shawarma an Ottawa obsession, especially as late-night food.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Shawarma Palace, Shawarma Station, and dozens of spots in ByWard Market. Open late for post-bar cravings. Ottawans are extremely particular about their shawarma loyalties.

hero_dishes.name: Peameal Bacon
hero_dishes.description: Canadian back bacon rolled in cornmeal, creating Ontario's signature bacon - leaner and meatier than American bacon
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally rolled in ground yellow peas (hence 'peameal'), this Toronto-born specialty became an Ottawa favorite. The cornmeal creates a slightly crunchy crust when pan-fried.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: ByWard Market vendors, breakfast restaurants. Try it in a sandwich, on eggs Benedict, or in peameal bacon poutine for an Ontario twist.

signature_drinks.name: Canadian Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Ottawa's thriving craft beer scene showcases Canadian brewing innovation
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Brewpubs in ByWard Market and Elgin Street. Beyond Beer in ByWard Market offers hundreds of local craft options. Patios in summer, cozy pubs in winter.

signature_drinks.name: Maple Whisky
signature_drinks.description: Canadian whisky infused with maple syrup - quintessentially Canadian
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Neat or on the rocks, celebrating Canada's maple heritage. Many Ottawa bars feature local maple-infused spirits and cocktails.

signature_drinks.name: Hot Chocolate on the Canal
signature_drinks.description: Rich, steaming hot chocolate served at BeaverTails stands and warming huts along the Rideau Canal Skateway
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential fuel for skating the 7.8km canal. Pairs perfectly with a cinnamon-sugar BeaverTail in -20Â°C weather.

food_culture_notes: ByWard Market (established 1826) is Canada's oldest and largest farmers' market - epicenter of Ottawa food culture
Bilingual city - menus and food culture reflect both English and French Canadian traditions
Winter food culture revolves around the Rideau Canal - skating, BeaverTails, hot chocolate, Winterlude festival
Shawarma loyalty runs deep - Ottawans have fierce allegiances to their favorite spots
Strong Lebanese, Vietnamese, Chinese, and Indian communities create diverse food scene
Government town culture - power lunch spots, diplomatic dining, formal restaurants
The 'Obama Cookie' at Moulin de Provence - maple leaf shortbread with red/white icing - became famous when Obama bought one in 2009
Winterlude festival (first three weekends of February) celebrates northern culture with food, ice sculptures, skating
